title: Veganism - The Causal Impotence Objection
description:
The causal impotence objection to veganism alleges that even if the production of meat is morally wrong, my decision to purchase meat makes no difference to the number of animals killed. My purchasing behaviour has no influence on meat production. So I have no reason to stop purchasing meat. This video examines this objection and some responses.

title: The Many Problems Problem
description:
For any method of belief formation, there are many objections to the view that the method is reliable. Suppose that for each objection, you have a response that you are reasonably confident is successful. Reasonable confidence in the success of *each* response leads to low confidence about the success of *all* responses. This is the many problems problem. This video outlines the problem in more detail and considers some responses.

title: Moral Contradictions
description:
Moral dialetheism is the view that some moral judgments are both true and false. In this video, I discuss the motivations for moral dialetheism, then turn to some of the challenges to the view. Finally, I outline moral trivialism, the view that all moral judgments are both true and false, as defended in the Tiantai Buddhist tradition.

description:

title: Conceivability and Possibility

title: Relaxed Realism in Metaethics
description:
According to relaxed realists, there are moral truths, but nothing in the world makes them truth. Moral truths have no ontological implications: we can believe that there are moral truths, without being committed to either natural or non-natural moral properties. This video explains relaxed realism and outlines some of the challenges facing the view.

title: Philosophical Pessimism
description:
"Life presents itself as a continual deception, in small matters as well as in great. If it has promised, it does not keep its word, unless to show how little desirable the desired object was; hence we are deluded now by hope, now by what was hoped for. If it has given, it did so in order to take. The enchantment of distance shows us paradises that vanish like optical illusions, when we have allowed ourselves to be fooled by them."

title: The Track Record Argument for Utilitarianism
description:
Utilitarianism has a strikingly good track record: utilitarians in previous centuries made moral claims that were considered outrageous at the time, but which have since become widely accepted. Is this a reason to believe utilitarianism?

title: Metaethics - Moral Convergence
description:
A striking fact of human history is the increasing convergence on liberal values. Michael Huemer argues that the best explanation for this convergence of moral belief is that humans are becoming better at discovering the moral facts. This video examines the moral convergence argument for moral realism.

Discord: https://discord.gg/RUjwFdDDtK
Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/kanebaker91

-- Cofnas, Nathan. (2020). "A debunking explanation for moral progress." Philosophical Studies 177(11): 3171-3191.
-- Huemer, Michael. (2016). "A liberal realist answer to debunking skeptics: the empirical case for realism." Philosophical Studies 173(7): 1983-2010.
-- Hopster, Jeroen. (2020). "Explaining historical moral convergence: the empirical case against realist intuitionism." Philosophical Studies 177(5): 1255-1273.

title: Metaethics - Kantian Constructivism
description:
This videos outlines Kantian constructivism in metaethics, as defended by Christine Korsgaard in "The Sources of Normativity". Korsgaard attempts to show that there are universal moral truths, and that these moral truths hold not in virtue of a mind-independent realm of moral facts, but follow simply from what is required in order to engage in rational action.

My Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/kanebaker91

Further reading on Kantian constructivism:
Gert, "Korsgaard's private-reasons argument"
Kerstein, "Korsgaard's Kantian arguments for the value of humanity"
Street, "What is constructivism in ethics and metaethics?"
Wallace, "The publicity of reasons"

title: Buddhism and Well-Being
description:
This video explores Buddhist views of well-being. First, I outline the well-being of unenlightened persons and the prevalence of suffering in ordinary lives. Then I turn to the "non-self" view and the cessation of suffering in enlightenment. I end by considering some difficulties for understanding Buddhist enlightenment in terms of well-being.

My Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/kanebaker91

The texts I mention at the beginning are Mark Siderits's book "Buddhism and Philosophy" and Christopher Gowans's article "Buddhist understandings of well-being", in "The Routledge Handbook of Philosophy of Well-Being"

title: Why I'm not a quasi-realist
description:

title: Metaethics - Quasi-Realism
description:
Quasi-realists hold that moral judgments are expressions of noncognitive states such as attitudes and plans for action. At first sight, this is a thoroughly antirealist position: if moral judgments are not standard beliefs, then there is no room for moral truth, moral facts, or moral progress. But the quasi-realist attempts to show that we can vindicate these apparently realist notions, even from a noncognitivist, antirealist starting point. This video outlines the approach to quasi-realism developed by Simon Blackburn.

My Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/kanebaker91

Blackburn 1993, "Essays in Quasi-Realism"
Blackburn 1999, "Is objective moral justification possible on a quasi-realist foundation?"
Cuneo 2017, "Quasi-realism" (in The Routledge Handbook of Metaethics)
Dreier 2004, "Meta-ethics and the problem of creeping minimalism"
Gibbard 2003, "Thinking How to Live"
Miller 2003, "An Introduction to Contemporary Metaethics", chapter 4

title: Scientific Realism - The Bad Lot Problem
description:
A central challenge to scientific realism is that inference to the best explanation is untrustworthy because there are often no grounds for supposing that true explanations were considered in the first place. For all we know, we might be inferring to the best of a bad lot. This video introduces this challenge.

My Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/kanebaker91

Further reading:
Dellsen, "Reactionary responses to the bad lot objection"
Khalifa, "Default privilege and bad lots"
Lipton, "Is the best good enough?"
Lipton, "Inference to the Best Explanation"
Wray, "Resisting Scientific Realism"

title: The Moral Argument Against Moral Realism
description:
This video outlines the moral argument against moral realism. I begin by presenting the case that non-naturalist realism is immoral, then I turn to some objections to the argument, and finally, I suggest how the argument might be extended to naturalist realism.

My Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/kanebaker91

I have drawn primarily from Hayward's article "Immoral Realism". Other articles on this topic:
Bedke, "A dilemma for non-naturalists: irrationality or immorality?"
Enoch, "Thanks, we're good: why moral realism is not morally objectionable"
Erdur, "A moral argument against moral realism"
Golub, "Is there a good moral argument against moral realism?"

title: A new skeptical challenge?
description:
I've forgotten all of the reasons for most of my views. I know that many of the arguments I found persuasive in the past would no longer be persuasive to me, were I to revisit them. Doesn't this undermine the justification for most of my views?

If you would like to help me forget more stuff, my Patreon is: https://www.patreon.com/kanebaker91

title: Can we perceive moral properties?
description:
If there are moral facts, how do we know about them? According to moral perceptualism, we can literally perceive moral properties. This videos outlines some of the arguments for and against moral perceptualism, and ends by considering whether moral perceptualism can solve the epistemological challenge to moral realism.

title: Skepticism and Explanation
description:
Is there justification for believing that our senses provide an accurate picture of the external world? A classic response to the skeptical challenge is that our commonsense view of the world is justified because it provides the best explanation of our sensory data. This video outlines this explanationist response and some of the objections that may be raised against it.

My Patreon:
https://www.patreon.com/kanebaker91

title: Misanthropy
description:
This video introduces some of the recent philosophical work on misanthropy. The third part is based on the work of Ian James Kidd, particularly his article "Varieties of Philosophical Misanthropy". See also Norlock's "Perpetual Struggle" and Halwani's "Misanthropy and Virtue". The notion of secular theodicies comes from Benatar's book "The Human Predicament", though his focus is on pessimism in general rather than misanthropy specifically.

My Patreon:
https://www.patreon.com/kanebaker91

title: Why Use Reason?
description:
Can reason be given a justification, or must it simply be presupposed? There seems to be nothing we can say in defense of reason without begging the question, because any argument for reason is itself an application of reason.

title: Marquis de Sade's Moral Philosophy
description:
This video outlines the Marquis de Sade's defense of immoralism, the view that morality is groundless, and that it is in our self-interest to act contrary to accepted norms: in particular, that we benefit from inflicting suffering and death on others.

I have drawn from arguments given by various characters in Juliette, Justine, and Philosophy in the Bedroom. There is not a great deal of secondary literature on Sade in the analytic tradition; however, Roche's article "Much Sense the Starkest Madness: Sade's Moral Scepticism" was useful, particularly for the first half the video.

My Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/kanebaker91

title: Induction Without Rules
description:
The material theory of induction, proposed by John Norton, holds that there are no universal rules of induction. Inductive inferences are not warranted by instantiating formal schemas analogous to the formal schemas of deduction, but rather by specific facts. This video outlines the case for the material theory.

My Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/kanebaker91

title: From noncognitivism to error theory

title: Science and Metaphysics
description:
Metaphysics aims to describe the fundamental nature of reality. A challenge to metaphysics is that it seems to have been displaced by the sciences: if we want to understand the way the world is, surely the best option is not to engage in philosophical speculation but to look at our best scientific theories. This video outlines four approaches to metaphysics that try to find a place for metaphysics as a useful field of inquiry alongside the sciences.

My Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/kanebaker91

title: Voluntarist Epistemology
description:
According to Bas van Fraassen's voluntarist epistemology, the only constraint on rational belief is consistency. Beyond this, our beliefs must be guided not by rules of reason, but by the passions: emotions, values, and intuitions. This video examines the grounds for voluntarism in the failure of traditional epistemology, and in the need for an epistemology that can properly accommodate conceptual revolutions. Then I turn to the objections to voluntarism.

My Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/kanebaker91

title: Philosophy of Science: The Strong Programme
description:
The strong programme in sociology of science is committed to providing sociological explanations of the development and content of scientific knowledge, and requires that the sociologist approach accepted scientific theories not as rational descriptions of a mind-independent world, but as social constructions. This video outlines the philosophical foundations of the strong programme.

title: Forgery and Aesthetic Value
description:
Many people suppose that forgeries of artworks are less aesthetically valuable than the originals, and that this would remain the case, even if the forgery were a perfect copy of the original. This video presents an explanation for why even a perfect forgery could be aesthetically deficient.

title: The Language of Nature
description:
According to realists, science discovers objective, mind-independent truths. To say that a proposition is true is to say that it corresponds to the world. Propositions are constructed from concepts, so for a proposition to correspond to the world, it seems that the world itself must somehow have a conceptual structure built into it. There must be a "language of nature" for the language of our theories to match. This video outlines some of the ways in which realists might conceive of the language of nature, plus some challenges to these positions.

My Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/kanebaker91

title: Science, Knowledge, and Complexity
description:
The complexity of the world outstrips our representational capacities, so that strictly speaking, almost nothing we say about the world is true. How should we think about knowledge given this fact, and what kind of knowledge do the sciences provide us? This video outlines some ideas developed by Paul Teller in a series of recent papers.

My Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/kanebaker91


Some papers by Teller --

Measurement accuracy realism
http://philsci-archive.pitt.edu/9740/1/Accuracy_MS_Final_4_30_13.pdf

Pan-perspectival realism explained and defended
https://philpapers.org/archive/TELPRE.pdf

Modeling truth
https://philpapers.org/archive/TELMT.pdf

Referential and perspectival realism
https://spontaneousgenerations.library.utoronto.ca/index.php/SpontaneousGenerations/article/view/26990


0:00 - Introduction
0:45 - Failure of referential realism
11:39 - Semantic alter-egos
19:37 - Measurement

title: The Problem of the Many
description:
For any visible object, there are many different sets of atoms that we could take as identical with the object. There are many sets of atoms that are equally good candidates for being the object. This seems to entail that what looked like one object is in fact many trillions of objects. This video outlines four solutions to this puzzle.

My Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/kanebaker91

title: Animals Don't Matter
description:
I take morality to be constituted by systems of rules constructed by rational agents for the benefit of rational agents. After outlining this perspective, I then deal with the marginal cases argument, which is the most popular objection to any view that denies animals moral standing. Next, I provide a limited defense of veganism from the point of view of human interests. I end by considering some of the sources of the sentimentality towards animals that prevails in our society.

My Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/kanebaker91

title: Anarcho-Primitivism
description:
Anarcho-primitivists argue in favour of dismantling civilization and shifting to a hunter-gatherer lifestyle. This video explains three central arguments for primitivism: (1) the reappraisal of hunter-gatherer life, (2) the environmental impact of civilization, and (3) the loss of autonomy under sophisticated technological systems. Next, I outline Zerzan's critique of symbolic thought, and finally, I discuss some standard objections to primitivism.

My Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/kanebaker91

title: The Puzzle of Non-Perceptual Art
description:
The puzzle of non-perceptual art arises from three independently plausible but mutually incompatible propositions:
(R) Artworks necessarily have aesthetic properties that are relevant to their appreciation as artworks.
(S) Aesthetic properties necessarily depend on properties perceived by the senses.
(X) There are artworks that need not be perceived by means of the senses to be appreciated as artworks.

This puzzle is discussed by James Shelley in his article "The problem of non-perceptual art". In this video, I examine Shelley's arguments and some of the responses.

My Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/kanebaker91

0:00 - The puzzle
8:19 - Solution 1: There are no non-perceptual artworks
24:36 - Solution 2: Some artworks are non-aesthetic
41:13 - Solution 3: Some aesthetic properties are non-perceptual

The image in the thumbnail is taken from a recording of Chris Burden's performance piece "Shoot": https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=drZIWs3Dl1k

title: Conceptual Engineering
description:
Conceptual engineering involves evaluating and designing concepts. It has recently been proposed as an important method for analytic philosophy, to replace the more widely accepted method of conceptual analysis. This video discusses the motivation for conceptual engineering and then examines one of the major objections to it.

description:
The principle of charity requires that we interpret text in a way that attributes the strongest possible position to the author. I discuss the motivation for this principle and raise some concerns about it.

title: Classification and Kinds: An Antirealist View
description:
This video presents an antirealist, constructivist approach to classification and kinds in science. First, I outline the traditional realist view. Then I introduce Ron Giere's "theoretical kinds", which are kinds defined in idealized models, and I elaborate on the ways in which scientists construct theoretical kinds out of the messy, complex worldly systems they are confronted with.

My Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/kanebaker91

title: How to be an empiricist
description:
This video examines stance empiricism, proposed by Bas van Fraassen in his book "The Empirical Stance". I begin by outlining some of the problems with standard definitions of empiricism, and then turn to van Fraassen's argument against construing empiricism as a belief. I then discuss the features of empiricism as a stance, and the empiricist critique of metaphysics.

title: Fallibilism
description:
There is a consensus among epistemologists in favour of fallibilism, the view that a person can know a proposition, even if that person does not have conclusive justification for the truth of that proposition. In this video, I begin by characterizing different versions of fallibilism, then I explain why most epistemologists are fallibilists. Next, I present four arguments against fallibilism.

title: So bad it's good
description:
What does it mean to say that an artwork is "so bad it's good"? This seems almost incoherent: how can something be good in virtue of its spectacularly bad features? In this video, I first define "good-bad" art, and then examine various philosophical explanations of it. Unfortunately, very little has been written by philosophers on this topic. This video draws mainly on Dyck and Johnson's article "Appreciating Bad Art".

2:19 - What is good-bad art?

28:21 - Good in virtue of non-aesthetic value
29:40 - Good in virtue of aesthetic value
32:24 - Bizarreness theory

title: Max Stirner - Anarchy
description:
This video examines Max Stirner's political philosophy. I begin by explaining the different forms of anarchism, then examine Stirner's critique of liberalism and socialism, focusing on the relation between the state and property ownership. Next, I present Stirner's egoist account of property, and then turn to Stirner's view of egoist social organization in general.

My first Stirner video on his concept of ownness: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BtDxBjfWoPc

0:00 - Intro
0:41 - Forms of anarchism
5:23 - Against liberalism
10:20 - Free markets
18:02 - Against socialism
25:23 - Egoistic property
31:22 - Stirner's anarchism
36:33 - Union of egoists
42:34 - Insurrection not revolution

As I said in the previous video, this is more an introduction to things that I find interesting in Stirner, than an introduction to Stirner. For the latter, SEP is, as always, a useful place to start: https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/max-stirner/

My Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/kanebaker91

title: Max Stirner - Ownness
description:
This video examines Max Stirner's egoism, focusing on ownness. I begin by explaining the role ownness plays in Stirner's egoism; then I examine Stirner's account of how individuals subjugate themselves by reifying abstractions; and finally, I present Stirner's critique of freedom and show how freedom contrasts with ownness.

My second video on Stirner: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_5qmDOf5SSk

0:00 - Intro
0:47 - Stirner's egoism
9:38 - Ownness vs "ordinary egoism"
14:05 - Reification
24:54 - Critique of freedom
37:05 - Summary

As I noted at the beginning of the video, this is more an introduction to things that I find interesting in Stirner, than an introduction to Stirner. For the latter, SEP is, as always, a useful place to start: https://plato.stanford.edu/entries/max-stirner/

My Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/kanebaker91

title: Anarchy in action
description: Cole discusses the dark web and explains how it provides an example of an efficient anarchist system.

title: The Experience Machine
description:
This video outlines Nozick's experience machine and the challenge it poses to hedonism, and then examines some potential hedonist responses.

Contents:
0:00 - Hedonism
3:00 - The experience machine argument
7:56 - Premise 1: Hedonism entails that plugging in would be best for you

20:51 - Objections to premise 2:

(iii) 27:25 - Irrational bias
(iv) 35:33 - Debunking the intuition

title: What is philosophy's most difficult problem?
description:
Let me know what you think.

title: Moral Disagreement
description:
Moral disagreement is often taken by laypersons to pose a serious challenge to moral realism. Although professional philosophers tend to be more dismissive of this argument, there are a variety of different ways of using moral disagreement against the realist, so it worth examining this problem in detail. This video examines several arguments from disagreement.

Contents:

0:00 - Introduction
Eight arguments from disagreement:
5:23 - Tolerance
8:49 - Self-evidence
11:02 - Inference to the best explanation
22:21 - The semantic argument
26:55 - Absence of a method for resolving disagreement
38:16 - Rationally irresolvable disagreement
44:16 - Undermining realist epistemology
48:38 - Moral intransigence
Two general problems for disagreement arguments:
1:03:26 - Self-defeat
1:05:29 - Moral agreement

title: Metaethics - Moral Naturalism 2: Cornell Realism
description:
I discuss Cornell realism, one of the most influential forms of non-reductionist moral naturalism.

Video contents:
0:00 - Introduction
0:52 - Why non-reductionism?
5:53 - Cornell realist semantics: causal regulation
15:15 - Goodness as a homeostatic property cluster
20:45 - Cornell realist epistemology: inference to the best explanation
28:50 - The explanatory impotence problem
38:38 - Explanatory virtues and moral explanation
47:00 - The Moral Twin Earth problem

Miller, "An Introduction to Contemporary Metaethics" and van Roojen, "Metaethics: A Contemporary Introduction" are very useful introductory books on this topic.

title: Answering the philpapers survey
description:
Here's the summary of my answers:

A priori knowledge - No
Abstract objects - Nominalism
Aesthetic value - Subjective
Analytic-synthetic distinction - No
Epistemic justification - Internalism
External world - Re epistemology, non-skeptical realism. Re metaphysics, agnostic.
Free will - Compatibilism
God - Agnostic
Knowledge - Empiricism
Knowledge claims - Relativism
Laws of nature - Humean
Logic - No fact of the matter
Mental content - No fact of the matter
Meta-ethics - Anti-realism
Metaphilosophy - Too unclear to answer
Mind - Non-physicalism
Moral judgment - Non-cognitivism
Moral motivation - Internalism
Newcomb's problem - One box
Normative ethics - Reject all
Perceptual experience - Disjunctivism
Personal identity - No fact of the matter
Politics - Libertarianism
Proper names - Fregean
Science - Anti-realism
Teletransporter - Death
Time - Agnostic
Trolley problem - Don't switch, but either is morally acceptable
Truth - Epistemic
Zombies - Inconceivable

title: Logical Nihilism
description:
This video outlines logical nihilism, the view that there are no laws of logic.

Papers by Gillian Russell:
(2017) "An introduction to logical nihilism"
(2018) "Logical nihilism: Could there be no logic?"
(2019) "Varieties of logical consequence by their resistance to logical nihilism"

description: Unfortunately, our conversation was cut a bit short this time because I started vomiting.

title: Strawson on panpsychism - reading group
description: We discuss Strawson's article "Realistic Monism", a defense of panpsychism. More of a reading duo than a reading group but it was still fun! Article available here: https://web.ics.purdue.edu/~drkelly/StrawsonRealisticPhysicalism2006.pdf

description: We look at Frege's article "On Sense and Reference". Cole has a video here giving some general background: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sDAIPwmCpLw

title: Observation, realism, and the extended mind
description:
In this video I examine the argument that the extended mind supports a realist account of observation in science. I propose an empiricist alternative.

0:00 - Scientific realism vs constructive empiricism
2:46 - The extended mind against empiricism
9:31 - An alternative, empiricist approach to scientific instruments
25:09 - What's wrong with Toon's parity argument?
35:33 - Beyond the parity principle?

title: Drunk Philosophy #1... "Show me the way to the next Schopenhauer"
description: I got drunk for the first time in my life and spent the night talking with Cole. Here are the highlights.

title: Metaethics - Moral Naturalism 1
description:
This video outlines moral naturalism and considers some of its benefits and drawbacks. Specific forms of naturalism will be examined in later videos.

Contents:
0:00 - introduction
1:35 - characterizing natural properties
5:27 - two forms of moral naturalism
8:41 - benefits of moral naturalism
16:02 - problems: the is/ought gap
22:20 - problems: Moore's open-question argument
32:00 - problems: normativity...
(i) 34:47 asymmetry of "because"
(ii) 38:20 standards
(iii) 40:16 moral motivation
(iv) 44:12 moral reasons
(v) 48:32 brute intuition

title: Analysis of Hume on personal identity / with Cole Nasrallah
description: Cole Nasrallah joins me to discuss an extract from Hume's Treatise.

title: Moral error theory... Now what?
description:
According to moral error theorists, all moral beliefs are false. This raises the question of what the error theorist should do with moral discourse. In this video, I outline four options.

Video contents:

0:00 - Outline of the debate
5:32 - Abolitionism
27:23 - Conservationism
40:43 - Fictionalism
1:08:09 - Substitutionism

title: Analysis of Swinburne on personal identity / with Cole Nasrallah
description: Apologies for the poor microphone quality on my end. We had some problems with the recording software. This will be fixed in later videos.

title: An argument against contextualism
description: What can contextualists contribute to the skepticism debate? Not much, I suggest.

title: Liberty / with Cole N.
description: I talk to Cole about libertarianism and anarchism, focusing mainly on the concept of negative liberty. There's also some bonus stuff about catcalling at the end. Cole's instagram: https://www.instagram.com/super_coleider/

title: Normativity, Moral and Epistemic
description:
One of the primary motivations for moral antirealism is that if there were moral facts, they would have metaphysically and epistemologically puzzling features: in particular, moral facts, if they existed, would be categorically normative. An important objection to moral antirealism is that epistemic norms seem to have the same objectionable features as moral norms. Epistemic norms and moral norms are "companions in guilt". Hence, the moral antirealist is committed to an implausible epistemic antirealism. This video outlines the companions-in-guilt argument, and then surveys a number of responses: embracing epistemic antirealism (epistemic error theory and epistemic expressivism), challenging the parity between moral and epistemic norms, and Cowie's dilemma.

0:00 - intro
0:30 - the queerness argument and categorical vs hypothetical imperatives
4:10 - the companions-in-guilt argument
9:40 - response #1: epistemic error theory
12:20 - Cuneo's objections to epistemic error theory
27:40 - response #2: epistemic expressivism
30:45 - Cuneo's objection to epistemic expressivism
37:30 - objection to both error theory and expressivism: might hypothetical norms be queer also?
46:15 - response #3: challenging the parity premise
55:00 - response #4: Cowie's dilemma for the companions-in-guilt argument

title: Metaphor
description: What is metaphorical meaning? This video examines three theories of metaphor: simile theory, Gricean theory, and the causal theory.

title: Scientific Realism 11 - Idealization
description: A serious threat to scientific realism arises from the fact that almost all scientific models involve idealizations: ideal gases, point masses, infinite populations, etc. Science is successful partially because scientists routinely appeal to assumptions that they know to be false. This suggests that the realist inference from the success of a theory to its truth is illegitimate. This video presents the idealization problem for scientific realism, and then examines three ways realists might respond: (1) eliminating idealizations; (2) quarantining idealizations; and (3) realism about idealizations. We will see that all of these solutions raise difficulties of their own.

title: Cole N. - Public Philosophy
description: I talk to philosopher Cole N. about the role of philosophy in everyday life, and whether philosophers should do more to promote public engagement with their subject. She then presents some objections to the arguments in my "Friends With Benefits" video. Cole is also a photographer and you should check out her instagram: https://www.instagram.com/super_coleider

title: Scientific Realism 12 - Scientific Practice
description: There are various arguments in the literature on realism that attempt to show that certain scientific practices presuppose a commitment to either realism or antirealism. This video examines these "scientific practice arguments".

title: What's the point of "art"?
description: Don't ask for the meaning, ask what's the point.

title: Beauty in Science
description:
What role does beauty play in scientific theorizing? The commonsense view is that aesthetic judgements are incidental to scientific research: it's nice if a theory is beautiful, but scientists should judge theories only based on the evidence. Beauty should not be a factor in theory choice. Yet this view is rejected by many scientists; for example, the physicist Paul Dirac once claimed that "it is more important to have beauty in one's equations than to have them fit experiment." What could justify this claim? This video explores different views about beauty in science.

4:09 - What makes a theory beautiful?
10:34 - Two views about beauty: Pythagoreanism and subjectivism
18:15 - Pseudo-aesthetic vocabulary
23:40 - Beauty as a tool
27:55 - Beauty as a tie-breaker
31:23 - Beauty and the Duhem-Quine thesis
37:31 - McAllister's aesthetic induction
48:45 - Beauty and understanding

title: Friends with benefits
description: In my view, a romantic relationship is simply a friendship with sexual intimacy. It follows that the very concept of a "friends with benefits" relationship - i.e. friends who have sex with each other, but who are not romantically attached - is incoherent. What am I missing?

title: Natural Kinds - Essentialism
description:
This video examines the essentialist account of natural kinds. I begin by outlining the basic commitments of essentialism. I then discuss Putnam's theory of the semantics of kind terms, a view which has been highly influential among modern essentialists. Finally, I examine essentialism in biology. The general consensus among philosophers is that essentialism fails as an account of kinds in biology. I explore some possible reasons for this.

0:01 - Introduction to natural kinds
5:10 - Basic commitments of essentialism
12:40 - Putnam's theory of meaning
28:40 - Why did essentialism fail in biology?

title: Apocalypse Now
description: Why should I do anything about the end of the world?

title: Sampling possibilities
description: Scientific models describe not just the actual but also the possible states of systems. Empiricists such as van Fraassen hold that these merely possible states do not correspond to anything real: modality is a feature of our models, not a feature of the world. In contrast, Ron Giere suggests that by manipulating a real system, we sample the possibilities described in the model of the system, and this justifies claims about the modal structure of the system.

title: Libertarianism as utopia
description: In this video, I examine Robert Nozick's argument that the libertarian minimal state is a framework for utopia.

title: Libertarianism and distributive justice
description: One of the most controversial aspects of libertarianism is its account of distributive justice. In this video, I explain why most libertarians reject wealth redistribution, focusing on libertarian arguments against taxation and on Robert Nozick's entitlement theory of justice. I also explore some arguments which suggest that wealth redistribution is compatible with libertarian principles.

title: Is there a moral duty to vote?
description: Many people hold that citizens of democracies have a moral duty to vote. In this video, we examine several arguments for and against this view.

title: üî¥
description: üî¥

title: Scientific expertise in philosophy of science
description: Many philosophers of science think that we can use philosophical tools to help resolve scientific problems. But do philosophers of science have the right kind of expertise to make useful contributions to scientific disputes?

title: Omniscience
description: What does it mean to say that God is "all knowing"?

title: Functionalism and multiple realizability
description: In philosophy of mind, the multiple realizability argument is one of the most popular arguments against type identity theory and in favour of functionalism. However, functionalism faces a multiple realizability problem very similar to the one raised against type identity theory. In this video I outline the functional multiple realizability problem and then briefly discuss four possible responses.

title: Philosophy of Science 17 - Feminist Approaches
description: Feminist epistemology urges that science should be reformed so as to incorporate feminist values. I begin by outlining some case studies of male bias in science. I then discuss three approaches to feminist epistemology: feminist empiricism, standpoint epistemology, and feminist postmodernism.

title: What philosophical positions annoy you?
description:
There are plenty of philosophical views that are wrong. But which ones do you think are not just wrong, but annoying?

The previous video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x7xm9n9NP4o

title: Radical scepticism
description: I disagree with radical scepticism. But more than that, I find it annoying. In this video I try to explore why.

title: Agnosticism
description: Here are my thoughts on two different definitions of "agnosticism", in the context of the debate about the existence of god.

title: Does the scientific realism debate matter?
description: I think it does.

title: What can selective realists believe?
description: What philosophy sounds like when it's done immediately after waking up at 4:30 in the afternoon.

description: üî¥

title: Philosophy of Science 16 - Bayesian Epistemology 2
description: In this video I outline some of the objections to Bayesianism.

title: Philosophy of Science 15 - Bayesian Epistemology 1
description: This video presents the fundamental ideas of Bayesianism, one of the most influential theories in modern philosophy of science. First I describe the three central tenets of Bayesianism, then I explain Bayes's theorem, and finally I describe the distinction between subjective and objective Bayesianism.

title: Philosophy of Science 14 - Novel Prediction
description: According to predictivism, the correct novel predictions of a theory confirm that theory more strongly than its accommodation of evidence that is already known. In this video I examine arguments for and against predictivism.

title: Scientism
description: It is common for people with physicalist or materialist views to be accused of "scientism". Some scientists and philosophers even openly embrace scientism. What is scientism, and what if anything is wrong with it? In this video we examine five objections to scientism.

title: Philosophical Progress 2
description: This video continues the discussion of philosophical progress. I outline some objections to the view of philosophy as conceptual analysis, then discuss two more views: philosophy as an exploration of theoretical landscapes, and philosophy as an incubator for new sciences.

title: Philosophical Progress 1
description: Does progress occur in philosophy? Modern philosophers still debate many of the same problems that were debated by the ancient Greeks. Despite thousands of years of debate, we have failed to achieve a consensus on many of the central philosophical questions. Why is this? What else could philosophical progress consist in?

title: Ethical Egoism 2
description:
This video examines some of the objections to ethical egoism.

0:00 - Repugnance
12:03 - Arbitrariness
18:07 - Conflicts of interest
23:23 - Rights
27:19 - Practical incoherence
32:33 - Moderate egoism

title: Ethical Egoism 1
description:
Ethical egoism is the view that people ought to act only in their own self-interest. In this video, I distinguish different forms of ethical egoism, outline some arguments in favour of ethical egoism, and discuss whether ethical egoism is genuinely an ethical theory. Objections to ethical egoism will be discussed in the next video.

0:00 - Introduction
2:15 - Types of ethical egoism
6:23 - Psychological egoism
15:27 - The social benefits of selfishness
23:50 - Responsibility for needs
30:53 - Why be moral?
33:09 - Is ethical egoism a moral theory?

title: A short argument for atheism
description: I present a quick argument against the existence of God.

title: üî¥
description: üî¥

title: Why I'm not a scientific realist
description:
Scientific realism is the view that our best scientific theories are approximately true and the entities postulated by those theories really exist. In this video I explain why I am no longer a scientific realist.

0:00 - Introduction
3:42 - Success and truth
12:50 - The selection argument
32:26 - The vulnerability criterion

title: Philosophy of SETI 5 - Carter's Argument
description: In this video I discuss an influential argument from Brandon Carter which tries to show that intelligent civilizations must be extremely rare.

title: Philosophy of SETI 4 - The Origin of Life
description: How prevalent is life in the universe? Does life emerge easily in a broad range of conditions, or does it require very specific conditions, and involve various highly improbable coincidences? In this video, I examine the attempts to estimate the fraction of habitable planets on which life arises.

title: Vexillology - My Favourite Flags
description: In this video I discuss my top ten favourite flags.

title: Vexillology - Basic Principles of Flag Design
description:
This video examines the five principles of flag design in NAVA's famous pamphlet "Good Flag, Bad Flag". I explain the reason behind these principles and also their limitations.

0:00 - Intro
1:18 - Keep it simple
5:47 - Use meaningful symbolism
9:15 - Use 2 to 3 basic colours
12:46 - No lettering or seals
18:46 - Be distinctive or be related
21:29 - The limits of the rules

title: Laws of Nature 2
description: In this video, I examine arguments against the necessitarian account of laws of nature.

title: Am I a Utilitarian?
description: No, I'm not. However I was asked to comment on the "Oxford Utilitarianism Scale".

title: Laws of Nature 1
description: In this video, I outline the debate between the regularity and necessitarian accounts of laws of nature. Regularity theory holds that laws of nature are nothing more than regularities/uniformities in the world. Necessitarian theory holds that laws of nature are "underlying principles" that literally govern the world; the laws necessitate the properties and behaviour of objects in the world, so that if it is a law that all Fs are Gs, this necessitates that a particular F is a G. This video outlines the arguments in favour of the necessitarian account. Arguments for the regularity theory will be discussed in the next video.

title: Philosophy of SETI 3 - Is SETI Scientific?
description: It has sometimes been argued that SETI is not properly scientific. This video examines two versions of this argument: first, the argument that SETI is unscientific because it is unfalsifiable; second, the argument that SETI is unscientific because there is no evidence, of the type that SETI searches for, that could convince us that extraterrestrial civilizations exist.

title: Philosophy of SETI 2 - The Drake Equation
description: This video discusses the Drake Equation, a tool used to estimate the prevalence of communicating civilizations, which has been the foundation for modern SETI research. I also examine the Fermi Paradox.

title: Philosophy of SETI 1 - Early History
description: In this video, I outline some of the early philosophical arguments concerning extraterrestrial life. Many people view speculation about extraterrestrials as a modern phenomenon, but there have been many times throughout history when people discussed the possibility of life beyond the Earth.

title: Freedom of Speech 1
description: In this video, I outline John Stuart Mill's classic arguments for freedom of speech from chapter 2 of "On Liberty".

title: Nature vs Nurture 4 - Scepticism
description: This video examines two view that are sceptical of the innate/acquired distinction - first, the claim that the distinction is simply a "disciplinary boundary marker", second, the claim that the distinction is completely misleading and should eliminated from proper scientific discourse.

title: Nature vs Nurture 3 - Canalization
description: In this video I examine Andr√© Ariew's proposal that a trait is innate just in case development of the trait is relatively insensitive to variation in the environment, i.e. the trait is canalized.

title: Newcomb's Problem
description: In this video I examine the debate about Newcomb's Problem, in which a group of philosophers who all have very little money try to convince you that a group of millionaires are the ones who have been financially irresponsible.
