title: Nature vs Nurture 2 - Adaptation
description: In this video, I examine the view that innateness is adaptation, an approach which has been especially influential for innate cognitive and behavioural capacities.

title: Nature vs Nurture 1 - Genetics
description: The distinction between innate and acquired characteristics is one of the most important problems in philosophy and science. In this video, I consider the proposal that we should take innate traits to be those traits that are encoded in the genes.

title: Scientific Experiment 1
description: In this series I examine how experiments are designed and the epistemological problems scientists face when conducting and interpreting experiments. This video begins with a discussion of Ignaz Semmelweis's attempts to understand the causes of childbed fever; then I outline two types of experiment, manipulative experiment and correlational experiment.

title: Biological Individuality 2
description: In this video, I first examine the theory of individuality developed by Peter Godfrey-Smith, who approaches the problem of individuality through an examination of biological reproduction. Next, I briefly outline the "extend organisms", the theory in certain contexts organisms can be built partially out of noncellular matter in the environment, and so literally extend into the environment.

title: Biological Individuality 1
description: What is an organism? This seemingly straightforward question is one of the central problems in philosophy of biology. In this video, first I outline a variety of entities that challenge our intuitive sense of what an organism is. Next, I consider two proposals for defining the organism: the genetic criterion and the immunity criterion.

title: Causation
description: In this video I outline various arguments which attack the view that causality is a genuine, objective feature of the world.

title: Philosophy of Humour 2
description: In this video, I examine the incongruity theory of humour, which holds that humour arises in situations that set up an expectation and then violate it.

title: Philosophy of Humour 1
description: This video examines two theories of humour which were popular in the past: the superiority theory, which holds that we feel humour when we compare ourselves to others and judge ourselves to be superior; and the relief theory, according to which humour is a mechanical release of mental tension.

title: Scientific Realism 11 (old version) - Models and Fictions
description: A serious threat to scientific realism arises from the fact that almost all scientific models involve fictions: frictionless planes, ideal gases, point masses, infinite populations, etc. Science is so successful partially because scientists routinely appeal to assumptions that they know to be false. This suggests that the realist inference from the success of a theory to its truth is illegitimate. In this video, I outline two different ways that fiction in science might challenge realism, and I consider some possible realist responses.

title: Scientific Realism 10 - Perspectivism
description: This video outlines scientific perspectivism, a more limited form of realism developed by Ron Giere.

title: Naturalized Metaphysics 2
description: This video outlines the principles of naturalistic metaphysics defended by James Ladyman and Don Ross. They argue that metaphysics should be concerned exclusively with attempting to unify scientific hypotheses. Then I present some objections that have been raised against Ladyman and Ross's programme.

title: Naturalized Metaphysics 1
description: Metaphysics in the analytic tradition generally proceeds without much attention to empirical science. Recently, a number of philosophers have argued that this kind of metaphysics is misguided and that metaphysicians should use science to inform their theorizing. This video outlines some of the objections to standard analytic metaphysics. The next video will examine the naturalistic alternative in more detail.

title: Philosophy of Science 13 - The Experimenter's Regress
description: In this video, I discuss the experimenter's regress, an argument proposed by Harry Collins that seems to challenge the rationality of science. Essentially, the regress is that in order to know that an experiment is giving us correct results, we need to know that we are using a reliable detector; but a reliable detector is just a detector that gives correct results, so we only know that our detector is reliable if we know that it's giving the correct results. We have a regress.

title: Intuitions in Philosophy 2
description: This video examines three further objections to the use of intuitions in philosophy.

title: Intuitions in Philosophy 1
description: Philosophers often use intuitions as evidence for or against philosophical theories. In this video, I review the role that intuitions play in philosophy and then I consider two objections to the appeal to intuition. Further objections will be discussed in the next video.

title: Scientific Progress
description: Most of us would agree that science has exhibited enormous progress over the last few hundred years. But what exactly does this progress involve? In this video, I outline three views of scientific progress: that progress consists in increased problem-solving ability, that progress is increasing nearness to the truth, and that progress is increasing knowledge.

title: Scientific Explanation 6 - Objections to the Unification Model
description:
This video outlines four objections to the unification model of scientific explanation.

Slides available here: http://www.mediafire.com/file/663y2uxwr2ax5di/uni.pptx

title: Scientific Explanation 5 - The Unification Model
description: This video examines the unification model of scientific explanation. According to this model, to explain an event is essentially to show that it is relevantly similar to some other phenomenon that we already understand. Explanation unifies phenomena.

title: Scientific Explanation 4 - Objections to the CM Model
description: In this video, I discuss some of the objections to the causal mechanical model.

title: Scientific Explanation 3 - The Causal-Mechanical Model
description:
This video discusses the causal-mechanical model of explanation, which claims that to explain an event is to cite the important causal processes and interactions leading to the event.

Slides for this video are available here: http://www.mediafire.com/file/h6h8cs83fl67686/causal.pptx

title: Scientific Explanation 2 - Objections to the DN Model
description:
As we have seen previously, the DN model requires that scientific explanations appeal to laws of nature. However, most sciences don't seem to be based on universal laws in the way that physics is. I first examine Hempel's attempt to modify the DN model so as to accommodate explanations without universal laws. Next, I outline some important objections to the DN model.

Slides available here: http://www.mediafire.com/file/iesqcksmgbo9tns/deductive1.pptx

title: Scientific Explanation 1 - The Deductive-Nomological Model
description:
It is often thought that science doesn't merely describe and predict what happens in the world, it also gives us explanations of why things happen. What is a scientific explanation? This video outlines the deductive-nomological model of explanation, proposed by Carl Hempel, which claims that to explain X is to show how X can be derived from statements of laws of nature plus initial conditions.

Slides available here: http://www.mediafire.com/file/ozfoi4zx4f436dn/deductive.pptx

title: Evolutionary Progress 2
description:
In this video, I examine the definition of evolutionary progress as increasing complexity over time. In particular, I examine the proposal that all biological systems are governed by a "zero-force law" that results in a universal tendency towards increased complexity.

Slides available here: http://www.mediafire.com/file/83qv1s3bgd66qtj/evo.pptx

title: Evolutionary Progress 1
description: When we consider the history of life, from simple self-replicating molecules to the incredible diversity and sophistication of the modern plants and animals, it seems intuitively obvious that evolution is in some sense progressive. However, biologists and philosophers over the last century have been extremely skeptical of the concept of evolutionary progress. In this video, I first discuss four common arguments against evolutionary progress, and then I consider two recent attempts to define "progress" in a scientifically acceptable way.

title: Philosophy of Science 12 - Science and Democracy
description:
Paul Feyerabend was once called "the worst enemy of science". In this video, we examine Feyerabend's arguments that science is unworthy of the exalted status it has in modern society, and that it should instead be treated as just one tradition among many.

Slides for the video can be downloaded here: http://www.mediafire.com/file/6e7677svr6hv7d6/feyerabend.pptx

title: Philosophy of Science 11 - Against Method 2
description: In this video, I finish outlining Feyerabend's arguments against method, and then I turn to some objections to his views.

title: Philosophy of Science 10 - Against Method 1
description: Paul Feyerabend held that there is no scientific method: all the methodological rules that philosophers have endorsed have been broken at various points in the history of science, and this has been to the benefit of science. Feyerabend defended this claim with an analysis of Galileo's arguments for heliocentrism.

title: Philosophy of Science 9 - Research Programmes
description: This video examines Lakatos's methodology of scientific research programmes. Lakatos greatly admired Karl Popper, and he attempted to develop a theory of scientific rationality inspired by Popper in a way that accommodated Thomas Kuhn's powerful historical arguments.

title: Risks of Active SETI
description: Active SETI involves sending messages into space to attempt to contact extraterrestrials. Various people have argued that active SETI carries substantial risks, since we do not know the character or the capabilities of the civilizations we may contact. This video examines some of these risks.

title: Adaptationism 2
description: This video explores recent developments in the debate about adaptationism. First I outline the distinction between three different forms of adaptationism: empirical adaptationism, explanatory adaptationism, and methodological adaptationism. Next, I consider how viewing evolutionary phenomena with different degrees of "zoom" alters the importance of selection and adaptations in evolutionary explanations. Finally, I briefly examine phylogenetics and evolutionary developmental biology as cases of non-adaptationist research programmes in modern biology.

title: Adaptationism 1
description: Adaptationism is the view that the primary cause of all evolutionary change is natural selection, and that the central goal of evolutionary biology is to explain adaptations. This video examines the criticisms of adaptationism made by Gould and Lewontin in their famous paper "The Spandrels of San Marco and the Panglossian Paradigm", and the alternatives approaches to evolutionary theory that they believe have been neglected.

title: The Paradox of Pornography
description: The paradox of pornography arises from the fact that we very rarely recognize porn films as art - let alone good art - yet porn film exemplifies many features that we usually associate with good art. This video examines some solutions to this paradox.

title: Fitness and Natural Selection
description: We are all familiar with the slogan "survival of the fittest". More accurately, we should probably say "survival and reproduction of the fittest". But what is fitness? It's tempting to say that fitness is a matter of reproductive success - the fitter organisms are those that have more surviving offspring. But then our slogan becomes a tautology. How should we define fitness? Does evolutionary theory rest on a tautology?

title: The St. Petersburg Paradox
description: This video explains the St. Petersburg paradox and considers a few possible solutions.

title: Is science contingent? 2
description: In this video, I examine four arguments against contingentism.

title: Is science contingent? 1
description:
Suppose that we replay the tape of the last few hundred years. Assume that, in our replay, the practice of science still exists and is properly resourced and rigorously conducted. Must this science develop in broadly the same way as our science, or could it be radically different? Could there be a successful science that does not postulate quarks, electrons, natural selection, Maxwell's equations, the second law of thermodynamics, etc?

Inevitabilists claim that any successful science must propose broadly the same theories as our science. Contingentists deny this. This video examines the arguments against inevitabilism.

title: Astrobiology - Planetary Habitability 2
description: This video examines how planetary mass, plate tectonics, giant planets, and the size of the moon can affect planetary habitability. I end with a discussion of "superhabitable" worlds.

title: Astrobiology - Planetary Habitability 1
description: Planetary habitability, the conditions required to support life, is a central concept in astrobiological research. This video discusses the circumstellar habitable zone and the galactic habitable zone.

title: Drone Music / "Cold Seep"
description: Here's a dark ambient piece I made, hope you enjoy.

title: Philosophy of Science 8 - Incommensurability
description: This video examines the incommensurability thesis, one of the most important and controversial ideas to come from Kuhn's work. I discuss three aspects of incommensurability: methodological incommensurability, the view that each paradigm supplies different standards of evaluation; observational incommensurability, the view that the theories we accept alter how we see the world; and finally, semantic incommensurability, which claims that as paradigms change, the very meanings of central theoretical terms also change.

title: Is there a shadow biosphere?
description: This video considers whether there might be a shadow biosphere, life that that arose independently from currently known life and that uses a radically different biochemistry. First I consider some of the ways life could in principle differ from life as we know it, then four arguments against the possibility of a shadow biosphere are examined.

title: Philosophy of Science 7 - Scientific Revolutions
description: This video details Thomas Kuhn's philosophy of science, which proposes a cyclical model of scientific development from normal science, to crisis, to revolution, then back to normal science. The important concepts of paradigms and paradigm shifts are explained.

title: The Epistemology of Disagreement 2
description: In this video, I examine several argument against Conciliation, the view that we should suspend judgement in response to peer disagreement.

title: The Epistemology of Disagreement 1
description: It is frequently the case that people who are my epistemic peers - i.e. people who are just as intelligent, well-informed, and unbiased as I am - disagree with my beliefs. A number of philosophers have argued that such peer disagreement should lead me to give up these beliefs, to suspend judgement on the issues in question. This video examines three arguments for this view.

title: Functions in Biology
description: This video discusses two analyses of function in biology: the causal role analysis, proposed by Robert Cummins, and the selected effect analysis, proposed by Ruth Millikan. First I outline the primary objections to the causal role analysis, which have led most philosophers to prefer Millikan's theory. Next, I explain why I think the selected effect analysis does not work. Finally, I defend the causal role analysis from the main objections.

title: Philosophy of Science 6 - Objections to Falsificationism
description: Karl Popper argued that induction should be eliminated from science, and he proposed as an alternative the method of falsificationism: scientists should proceed by making bold, risky hypotheses followed by attempted refutations. This video outlines six objections that have been raised against Popper's falsificationism.

title: Philosophy of Science 5 - Falsificationism
description: In previous videos, we have seen that induction and confirmation face a variety of difficulties. Karl Popper attempted to solve the problem of induction not by showing that induction is justified, but rather by showing that induction can be eliminated: science doesn't actually use induction at all. This video examines Popper's anti-inductivist model of the scientific method, falsificationism.

title: Philosophy of Science 4 - Goodman's Problem of Induction
description: This video outlines Goodman's "new riddle" of induction, which potentially provides additional reason to be skeptical of inductive inference. The consequences of Goodman's problem are discussed, and four potential solutions are considered.

title: Philosophy of Science 3 - Hume's Problem of Induction
description: We have noted previously that science appears to be built on induction. David Hume famously argued that induction is not rationally justified: inductive arguments provide no reason whatsoever to believe their conclusions. If science is inductive, then Hume's argument seems to show that the foundations of science are irrational. This video explains Hume's argument and considers a few possible responses.

title: Philosophy of Science 2 - The Hypothetico-Deductive Method
description: In this video I outline the hypothetico-deductive method and then consider five objections to it, including the problem of irrelevant conjunctions and the ravens paradox.

title: Philosophy of Science 1 - Induction and Naive Inductivism
description:
In this video, I outline the difference between inductive and deductive reasoning, and then examine the "naive inductivist" model of the scientific method, according to which science essentially involves collecting a large number of unbiased observations and then drawing inductive generalizations on the basis of these.

This series is not based on any particular book, but "Understanding Philosophy of Science" by James Ladyman and "Theory and Reality" by Peter Godfrey-Smith are two introductions to philosophy of science that have been helpful to me, and are good places to go for further reading. I also recommend "Representing and Intervening" by Ian Hacking. This was written in 1983, so it's somewhat dated now, but it's worth reading because it emphasizes that philosophers of science need to attend to the details experimentation and scientific practice. Most philosophy of science until recently was focused on theory and other more "abstract" matters; Hacking provides an interesting alternative approach.

title: Philosophy of Rainbows
description: Bas van Fraassen holds that rainbows are not real entities but instead should be considered "public hallucinations". I criticize van Fraassen's view and offer a realist alternative.

title: Biology of Race 2
description: This video examines two further arguments against the view that races are biologically real: (4) Lewontin's argument that the vast majority of genetic variation obtains within races, rather than between races; and (5) the argument that patterns of variation are completely discordant.

title: Biology of Race 1
description: Is race a legitimate biological classification? In this video, I first outline three general views of the concept of race: naturalism, eliminativism, and constructivism. I then examine three arguments against the view that races are biologically real: (1) human variation is gradual not discrete, hence any division into races is arbitrary; (2) humanity is too young for significant biological differences between populations to have evolved; (3) human populations have always interbreed, hence are unlikely to be significantly differentiated. Further arguments will be examined in the next video.

title: Personal Identity 6 - Transhumanism
description: This video examines how the problem of personal identity arises in the context of transhumanism. Transhumanism is the view that technological developments in the near future will allow us to make radical improvements to human bodies and minds. An objection to the transhumanist project is that such enhancements would alter us so much that our personal identity would be destroyed - in other words, enhancement would literally be suicide. This video evaluates this objection.

title: Drone Music / "Mare Imbrium" 3
description: Final part.

title: Drone Music / "Mare Imbrium" 2
description: Part 2 of the ambient piece.

title: Drone Music / "Mare Imbrium" 1
description: Part 1 of an ambient piece I made. Hope you enjoy!

title: Personal Identity 5 - The Narrative Theory
description: This video examines the narrative theory of personal identity, which claims that personal identity is constituted by the stories we tell ourselves of our own lives.

title: Ethics - Selective Abortion
description: Prenatal testing for disorders such as Down syndrome is widespread, and many abortions are performed as a result of such tests. Some philosophers in the disability rights movement have argued that selective abortion of disabled foetuses is ethically questionable, in that it contributes to discrimination against people with disabilities. This video examines some of these arguments.

title: Personal Identity 4 - Multiple Personality
description:
Throughout this series we have seen that multiple personality disorder (today more commonly known as dissociative identity disorder) has been used to support or challenge certain theories of personal identity. This video examines the disorder and its relation to personal identity in more detail.

I focus on two questions. First, does dissociative identity disorder provide an example of multiple people in one body, or should it be understood as involving altered states of a single person? Second, should people with dissociative identity disorder be held morally or legally responsible for transgressions committed by an alter personality?

title: Philosophy of Dreaming 2
description: In this video, I examine some objections to Ichikawa's theory that dreams are constructed of imagery, not hallucinations. I then consider Melanie Rosen's arguments for the claim that memories of dreams are usually inaccurate and should not be trusted.

title: Philosophy of Dreaming 1
description: The standard view of dreams is that dreams are hallucinatory experiences that occur during sleep. Today I examine two challenges to this view: Dennett's "cassette theory" which holds that dreams are not experiences at all, but rather false narratives composed during sleep and then inserted into our memories on awakening; and Ichikawa's theory that dreams are not hallucinations, but are constructed out of mental imagery.

title: Guitar Music
description: The artwork is by Henry Holmes Smith.

title: Personal Identity 3 - Nihilism
description: In the context of personal identity, nihilism is the view that there is no persistence over time. This video examines the nihilist "bundle theory" suggested by David Hume, according to which I am nothing but a constantly changing bundle of mental states, and there is no self that persists through these changes.

title: Personal Identity 2 - Animalism
description: Animalism is the theory that you are an animal: you persist just as long as the biological processes that keep your body alive, such as metabolism, blood circulation, temperature regulation, and so on, continue. While this theory is intuitively plausible, we will see that it faces some serious problems.

title: Personal Identity 1 - Psychological Continuity
description:
In this series I will examine various theories of personal identity, starting with the theory that personal identity is secured by psychological continuity.

When I look at an old school photo, I can point to one of the children and say "that's me." But I am very different in many ways from the child in that photo. So what is it that makes me the same person as that child? The psychological continuity theory points to the fact that I psychologically evolved out of that child. I will outline the basic claims of this theory and then consider three objections: the circularity objection; the objection from the possibility of sudden psychological change; and the fission/fusion objection.

title: Metaphysics - Levels of Reality
description: It is natural to think of the world as being divided into a hierarchy of levels: on the lowest level there are fundamental particles such as quarks, electrons, photons, etc; at a higher level, atoms and molecules; at a higher levels, cells; at a higher level, organisms; and so on. This video examines various ways we might try to make the notion of levels precise. I then outline Jaegwon Kim's exclusion argument, which poses a serious problem for the levels picture.

title: Philosophy of Photography - Realism and Transparency
description: This video examines Kendall Walton's transparency thesis, which claims that when we look at a photograph of an object, we do not simply see a representation of the object; rather we "see through" the photograph to the object itself. I consider (a) how transparency relates to the realism of photography, (b) Walton's arguments for transparency and (c) various criticisms of transparency, in particular focusing on the objection that Walton's view rests on a faulty account of perception.

title: Folk Psychology 2 - The Theory-Theory 2
description: Continuing the discussion of the theory-theory, which claims that folk psychology is literally a theory, analogous to scientific theories. In this video I examine the view that the theory is in some sense innate, rather than learned.

title: Folk Psychology 1 - The Theory-Theory 1
description: "Folk psychology" refers to our capacity to explain and predict the behaviour of other people by attributing mental states to them. This video examines the theory-theory, which claims that folk psychology is literally a theory, analogous to scientific theories.

title: Kripke's Meaning Skepticism 3 - A Straight Solution
description: A straight solution to the paradox is outlined and defended. This solution has been suggested by Craig Delancey, and it says that plus is simpler than quus, and that humans should (and generally do) use simpler rules for producing and recognizing meaningful utterances.

title: Kripke's Meaning Skepticism 2 - The Skeptical Solution
description: This video details Kripkenstein's "skeptical solution", which accepts the conclusion of the skeptical argument that there are no meanings, but then tries to show how we are justified in ascribing meanings to ourselves and to others.

title: Kripke's Meaning Skepticism 1
description: This video examines Kripke's rule following paradox, which aims to show that there is no fact of the matter what any of the words we use mean.

title: Philosophy of Sex - Consent 5
description: In this video, I look at two more arguments for the queer theory. Then I examine David Benatar's challenge that the liberal view cannot explain the wrongness of rape and paedophilia.

title: Philosophy of Sex - Consent 4
description: According to the liberal view, consent is necessary and sufficient for sexual activity to be morally acceptable: provided that all parties are consenting, you can do whatever you like. This video examines two challenges to the liberal view: radical feminism and queer theory.

title: Scientific Realism 9 - The Natural Ontological Attitude
description: This video examines Arthur Fine's natural ontological attitude (NOA), a position designed to be a minimalist compromise between realism and antirealism.

title: Scientific Realism 8 - Structural Realism
description: In this video I introduce structural realism, the view that we should be skeptical of what our best theories tell us about unobservable entities, but be realist about the structural or mathematical claims.

title: Scientific Realism 7 - Entity Realism
description: Entity realism, most famously defended by Ian Hacking, is the view that we should believe in the unobservable entities postulated by scientists, but be skeptical of scientific theories. In this video I examine Hacking's "manipulation argument" for entity realism, which claims that we must believe in those unobservable entities that we can use as tools for studying other phenomena.

title: Scientific Realism 6 - Observation
description: Many antirealists rely on the distinction between observables and unobservables, since they assert that science gives us knowledge of the former, but not the latter. In this video, I examine the distinction, and I consider some of the arguments realists have used to try to undermine its significance.

title: Scientific Realism 5 - Unconceived Alternatives
description: This video examines Kyle Stanford's argument from unconceived alternatives, which essentially combines the pessimistic induction and underdetermination arguments. The argument from unconceived alternatives begins with the claim that over the history of science, there were equally good alternatives to past-accepted theories that past scientists failed to conceive of. So, there are probably equally good alternatives to currently accepted theories that modern scientists fail to conceive of. Hence we should not believe that currently accepted theories are true.

title: Scientific Realism 4 - Underdetermination
description:
The underdetermination of theory by data is the claim that every currently accepted theory has rivals that are empirically equivalent, i.e. that make the same claims about the behaviour of the observable world. For instance, there is a physical theory that doesn't postulate electrons but that is just as compatible with the evidence as the theory we accept. So, we should not believe in the truth of currently accepted theories.

This video explains the underdetermination argument in detail and then examines various problems for it, including non-empirical virtues, confirmation holism, and the theory-ladenness of observation.

title: Scientific Realism 3 - Pessimistic Induction
description:
The pessimistic induction is the primary argument against scientific realism. It claims that since many of the best scientific theories of the past have been rejected, we should expect that many of the best scientific theories we currently hold will be rejected in the future. Hence, we should not believe that our best scientific theories are true.

This video develops the pessimistic induction in more detail and then examines various ways that scientific realists might respond.

title: Scientific Realism 2 - The No-Miracles Argument
description: I examine the no-miracles argument for scientific realism, which claims that the best explanation for the success of science is that our best scientific theories are approximately true.

title: Scientific Realism 1 - Introduction
description: This series explores scientific realism, the view that our best scientific theories accurately describe the world and that we should believe in the entities and properties postulated by them. In the video, I first define scientific realism more precisely; then I outline various alternatives to realism; and I finally I briefly discuss  two popular variations on realism, entity realism and structural realism.

title: Philosophy of Colour 3.2 - Primitivism 2
description: The video examines further objections to colour primitivism: (1) the evolutionary debunking argument against primitivism; (2) the argument from variation in colour perception; and (3) the argument that the primitivist strategy could save various "deviant" properties. I also examine colour pluralism, the view that a surface can have many, perhaps infinitely many, colours all over at the same time.

title: Philosophy of Colour 3.1 - Primitivism 1
description:
Colour primitivism claims, like colour reductionism, that colours are mind-independent and non-relational: the colour of an object is an intrinsic property of the object, not dependent on the relation between the object and a perceiver or the relation between the object and its surroundings. However, the primitivist holds that colours are irreducible. They exist "over and above" physical properties such as wavelength and spectral reflectance.

The video outlines colour primitivism and then examines two objections: (1) the "downward causation" argument that views such as primitivism cannot account for the causal powers of colours; (2) the argument that primitivism faces a skeptical problem. Further objections will be dealt with in the next video.

title: Philosophy of Colour 2.2 - Reductionism 2
description: One of the primary objections to colour reductionism is that it is incompatible with the facts about the structure of colour space, since certain necessary features of colours cannot be mapped to physical properties such as spectral reflectances. I examine five different ways of running this argument: (1) unique hues; (2) saturation; (3) opponency; (4) related vs unrelated colours; (5) relations of similarity between colours.

title: Philosophy of Colour 2.1 - Reductionism 1
description: This video examines colour reductionism, which holds that colours are reducible to standard physical properties. I focus mainly on Alex Byrne and David Hilbert's proposal that colours are surface spectral reflectances. I then examine how metamerism poses a challenge to colour reductionism. (The next video will deal with further objections to reductionism.)

title: History of Biology - Darwin 1
description:
Darwin's theory of evolution by natural selection is probably the most significant scientific development in biology. This video examines Darwin's broader scientific views: I discuss the influence on Darwin of Charles Lyell's uniformitarianism, and how Darwin attempted to develop a proper scientific methodology for natural history.

I briefly discuss the influence of William Paley on the development of natural selection. I will cover natural selection in detail in the next video.

Most of this video is based on chapter 2 of Stephen Jay Gould's "The Structure of Evolutionary Theory". Although fairly technical, chapters 2-7 of Gould's book are an excellent source for the history of 19th and early 20th century biology.

title: Philosophy of Colour 1 - Colour Science
description:
In this series, I will introduce various philosophical theories of colour. However, in order to understand the philosophy of colour, it is important to have at least a basic grasp of colour science. This video briefly outlines: the physical causes of colour; the structure of the retina; two central theories of colour perception, the trichromatic theory and the opponent-process theory; and the phenomenon of colour constancy.

The majority of this video was drawn from "Color for Philosophers" by C.L. Hardin and "Neuroscience: Exploring the Brain" by Bear, Connors, and Paradiso, chapter 9 ("The Eye").

title: Philosophy of Emotion 2 - Cognitive Theories
description: In this video I examine cognitive theories of emotion, which hold that emotions necessarily involves thoughts or cognitions. I focus mainly on Richard Lazarus's appraisal theory, and then outline a number of objections to cognitive theories given by Robert Zajonc.

title: Philosophy of Emotion 1 - The James-Lange Theory
description: I examine the James-Lange theory of emotion, according to which emotions are simply feelings of bodily processes.

title: Modal Realism 3 - Objections
description: I examine five objections to modal realism: (1) Modal realism commits us to an unacceptable ontology; (2) What happens at other possible worlds is simply irrelevant to the modal facts at this world; (3) Modal realism undermines modal knowledge; (4) Many possibilities are excluded by modal realism, hence it is an inadequate account of modality; (5) Modal realism leads to moral indifference.

title: Modal Realism 2
description: In this video, I first examine Lewis's arguments for modal realism, and then I briefly consider some alternative approaches to possible worlds and why Lewis thinks these should be rejected.

title: Modal Realism 1
description: In this video, I outline David Lewis's theory of modal realism, according to which all possible worlds exist in just the same way the actual world does. First, I discuss the concept of modality and explain why philosophers have found it fruitful to appeal to possible worlds in philosophical analysis. Then I examine in detail the commitments of Lewis's realist theory.

title: Philosophy of Sex - Consent 3
description: In sex, as in many other domains, consent is of central importance. But what exactly is consent? In this video, I consider the ontology of consent, and focus on two basic approaches: subjectivism, according to which consent is a kind of mental state; and performativism, according to which consent is a matter of performing certain actions.

title: Philosophy of Sex - Consent 2
description:
In sex, as in many other domains, consent is of central importance. But what exactly is consent? Under what conditions can we say that a person has consented to sex? In this I continue examining three of the factors that can undermine consent: coercion, deception, and intoxication.

Article mentioned at 23:25: http://www.slate.com/articles/double_x/doublex/2015/02/drunk_sex_on_campus_universities_are_struggling_to_determine_when_intoxicated.html

title: Philosophy of Sex - Consent 1
description: In sex, as in many other domains, consent is of central importance. But what exactly is consent? Under what conditions can we say that a person has consented to sex? In this video and the next, I examine three of the factors that can undermine consent: coercion, deception, and intoxication.

title: Philosophy of Medicine - What is Disease? 2
description: In this video, I examine two more theories of disease: social constructivism and disease eliminativism.

title: Environmental Ethics - Nature Restoration
description:
In this video I examine the ethics of environmental restoration, focusing on Robert Elliot's famous paper "Faking Nature". 

Based on my blog post: http://kfbaker.blogspot.co.uk/2016/01/robert-elliot-faking-nature.html

title: Could we communicate with extraterrestrials?
description:
In this video, I discuss Andr√© Kukla's paper "One World, One Science", which concerns the question of whether, if we were ever to meet an extraterrestrial race, we could learn to communicate with them.

Based on my blog post: http://kfbaker.blogspot.co.uk/2016/01/could-we-communicate-with.html

title: Philosophy of Medicine - What is Disease? 1
description: Disease has always been one of the central problems in human lives. But what exactly is disease? In this video, I present two theories of disease: Christopher Boorse's the biostatistical theory, which treats disease as purely biological state; and Lennart Nordenfelt's holistic theory, which sees health and disease as fundamentally connected to values and happiness.

title: Philosophy of Mind 6.1 - The Extended Mind
description: In this video, I introduce the extended mind hypothesis, according to which mental states and processes are partially constituted by states and processes in the external environment, beyond the brain and body. First, I outline the arguments in Clark & Chalmers' classic paper "The Extended Mind", then I turn to two recent developments: extended affectivity and the socially extended mind.

title: The Evolutionary Theory of Rape 2
description: In this video, I examine several problems for the evolutionary theory of rape.

title: The Evolutionary Theory of Rape 1
description: As an example of evolutionary psychology in action, in this video I outline the evolutionary theory of rape, which has been defended most famously by Randy Thornhill, Nancy Thornhill, and Craig Palmer.

title: Philosophy of Mind - Animal Minds 1
description: In this video, I examine three arguments from Donald Davidson for the fairly striking conclusion that non-human animals have no beliefs.

title: Evolutionary Psychology
description:
I outline the foundations of Evolutionary Psychology, a research programme pioneered by Leda Cosmides and John Tooby that makes five core claims:

(1) Evolutionary theory should be given a central place in psychology, just like it has in biology.
(2) Massive modularity: the mind is not composed of "general-purposes" mechanisms, such as a general-purpose reasoning mechanism or a general-purpose learning mechanism, but instead consists of hundreds or thousands of highly specialized modules that provide us with innate knowledge of and innate abilities in various domains.
(3) Most of these modules evolved during our time in Pleistocene hunter-gatherer societies.
(4) These modules are universal to all human populations. They constitute an invariant human nature.
(5) If we accept the above points, the standard methodology of psychological research will have to be altered.

title: Punctuated Equilibrium 3 - Objections 2
description: I continue examining some of the objections that are raised against punctuated equilibrium. In this video, I consider the objections that punctuated equilibrium is contradicted by the fossil record; that the model of speciation on which it is based - Mayr's model of peripatric speciation as leading to genetic revolutions - is untenable; and that "phyletic gradualism", the theory that Gould and Eldredge attribute to their opponents, is a strawman.

title: Punctuated Equilibrium 2 - Objections 1
description: I examine several of the objections that have been raised against punctuated equilibrium: that punctuated equilibrium is trivial/tautologous; that it is untestable; and that it is testable but has been refuted.

title: Punctuated Equilibrium 1
description: In this video, I outline punctuated equilibrium, a theory about macroevolution proposed in 1972 by Niles Eldredge and Stephen Jay Gould. I examine the foundations of punctuated equilibirum, particularly its basis in Mayr's theory of peripatric speciation, and then deal with some common misconceptions.

title: Philosophy of Biology - The Species Problem 2
description: Species is one of the fundamental units of biological taxonomy. But what exactly is a species? In this video, I examine the cohesion species concept, the phylogenetic species concept, and species pluralism.

title: History of biology: the objections to Darwinism 2
description: For several decades prior to the modern evolutionary synthesis in the 1930s, Darwinism (the theory that natural selection is the primary mechanism of evolution) was widely rejected by the scientific community. In this video, I examine some of the scientific objections that were raised against Darwinism.

title: History of biology: the objections to Darwinism 1
description: For several decades prior to the modern evolutionary synthesis in the 1930s, Darwinism (the theory that natural selection is the primary mechanism of evolution) was widely rejected by the scientific community. In this video, I examine some of the scientific objections that were raised against Darwinism.

title: Should incest be legalized?
description:
In this video, I argue that laws against incest should be abolished. I examine and criticize five arguments in favour of incest laws:

1. The genetic defects argument.
2. The integrity of the family argument.
3. The role of each family member argument.
4. The prevention of abuse argument.
5. The perversion argument.

title: John Cage's 4'33"
description:
In this video, I explore some of the ideas behind John Cage's most controversial composition, 4'33".

If you're interested in learning more about 4'33" or John Cage in general, I recommend the books "No Such Thing As Silence" by Kyle Gann and "The Roaring Silence" by David Revill.

title: Philosophy of Biology - The Species Problem 1
description: Species is one of the fundamental units of biological taxonomy. But what exactly is a species? In this video, I critically introduce three definitions: the morphological species concept, the biological species concept, and the ecological species concept.

title: Is Pluto a planet?
description: Pluto was once classified as a planet, but in 2006 was demoted to "dwarf planet" by the IAU. In this video, I examine the problems that lead to Pluto's demotion, and then analyse the IAU's definition of "planet". I consider whether we should adopt a different definition of "planet", perhaps one that would include Pluto again.

title: Metaethics 7 - Moral Realism:  Non-Naturalism 2
description: In this video, I examine four objections to Moore's open-question argument, then five objections to intuitionism more generally.

title: Metaethics 6 - Moral Realism: Non-Naturalism 1
description: In this video, I examine moral non-naturalism, a form of moral realism. First I outline some general motivations for moral realism, then I present G.E. Moore's use of his "open-question argument" to defend non-naturalism.

title: Art and Ethics 4 - Variabilism
description:
Does the moral value on an artwork influence its aesthetic value? If an artwork is sexist, racist, pro-Nazi, etc, does this count against its value as an artwork? Or when judging art, should we put our moral reactions to one side?

In this video, I examine variabilism, which holds that a moral defect is sometimes an aesthetic virtue and sometimes an aesthetic defect.

title: The Ethics of Terraforming 2
description: In this video, I examine one more argument against terraforming, then present three "deep green" defenses of it.

title: The Ethics of Terraforming 1
description: In this video, I examine some ethical objections to terraforming.

title: Art and Ethics 3 - Moralism
description:
Does the moral value on an artwork influence its aesthetic value? If an artwork is sexist, racist, pro-Nazi, etc, does this count against its value as an artwork? Or when judging art, should we put our moral reactions to one side?

In this video, I examine moderate moralism, the view that a moral defect is sometimes an aesthetic defect; and ethicism, the view that a moral defect is always an aesthetic defect.

The artists shown towards the end of the video are (in order):

Otto Dix
Francis Bacon
Wangechi Mutu; Philippe Pasqua
Leonard da Vinci
Goya; Zdzis≈Çaw Beksi≈Ñski

title: Art and Ethics 2 - Autonomism
description:
Does the moral value on an artwork influence its aesthetic value? If an artwork is sexist, racist, pro-Nazi, etc, does this count against its value as an artwork? Or when judging art, should we put our moral reactions to one side?

In this video, I examine five arguments for autonomism, the view that moral value and aesthetic value are totally independent.

title: Metaethics 5 - Subjectivism 2
description: In this video, I examine two universalist forms of subjectivism: ideal observer theory and (more briefly) divine command theory.

title: Art and Ethics 1 - Introduction
description:
Does the moral value on an artwork influence its aesthetic value? If an artwork is sexist, racist, pro-Nazi, etc, does this count against its value as an artwork? Or when judging art, should we put our moral reactions to one side?

In the video, I outline the main views about the relation between moral and aesthetic value.

title: Can we accept the Repugnant Conclusion? 2
description: In this video, I finish looking at strategies for accepting the Repugnant Conclusion.

title: Can we accept the Repugnant Conclusion? 1
description: Recently, a number of philosophers have argued that we should accept, rather than try to avoid, the Repugnant Conclusion (or the Mere Addition Paradox) in population ethics. In this video, I outline the Repugnant Conclusion, and consider some strategies for accepting it.

title: Philosophy of Art - The Paradox of Tragedy 2
description: The second and final part of my introduction to the paradox of tragedy. I examine quasi-emotion theory, control theory, relief-from-boredom theory, and rich experience theory.

title: Philosophy of Art - The Paradox of Tragedy 1
description: Why do we seek out and enjoy artworks that produce negative emotions, such as sadness, fear, and disgust? In this video, I outline the paradox of tragedy, and then consider a family of responses known as 'hedonic compensation theories'.

title: Philosophy of Art - The Paradox of Fiction 2
description: The second and final part of my introduction to the paradox of fiction. In this video, I examine two popular theories, counterpart theory and thought theory, and two rather less popular ones, nonrationality theory and existence theory.

title: Philosophy of Art - The Paradox of Fiction 1
description:
In this video, I explain the paradox of fiction, and consider three responses to it: irrationality theory, illusion theory, and quasi-emotion theory.

I will examine some more responses to the paradox in part 2.

title: Metaethics 4 - Subjectivism 1
description: In this video, I examine two relativist forms of subjectivism: individualist subjectivism and cultural subjectivism.

title: Metaethics 3 - Error Theory
description: An introduction to metaethical error theory.

title: Metaethics 2 - Emotivism
description: In this video, I examine emotivism. I look at A.J. Ayer and C. L. Stevenson's defences of emotivism, and then outline a number of objections to the theory.

title: Metaethics 1 - Introduction
description: In this video, I briefly explain the main positions in metaethics. I then outline two important metaethical problems: the is-ought gap and the fact-value distinction.

title: Perception - Idealism
description:
An introduction to idealism as defended by George Berkeley.

0:00 - Introduction
0:56 - Defeating skepticism
3:57 - Empiricism
6:32 - Primary and secondary qualities
14:03 - Berkeley's Master Argument
17:25 - Objections to idealism
28:58 - Berkeley's appeal to God
34:40 - Skepticism again

title: Philosophy of Mind 5.2 - Objections to Eliminative Materialism
description:
In this video, I examine some objections to eliminativism. I begin with two "commonsense" objections: first, that eliminativism is just too absurd to take seriously; second, that eliminativism is self-refuting.

Then I turn to the debate about the status of folk psychology. There are two ways a defender of folk psychology can proceed. He may argue either that folk psychology is not a theory, and hence it's absurd to judge it as you would judge a scientific theory; or that folk psychology is a theory, but it's perfectly adequate.

Finally, I turn to the objection that eliminativism presupposes an untenable theory of reference.

title: Philosophy of Mind 5.1 - Eliminative Materialism
description: In this video, I examine eliminative materialism (eliminativism), the view that mental states simply don't exist. In particular, I focus on the version of eliminativism defended by Paul Churchland.

title: Philosophy of Mind 4.2 - Objections to Functionalism
description:
I examine some of the main objections to functionalism, including the inverted qualia problem and John Searle's Chinese Room thought experiment.

7:05 - On the incoherence of inverted colour qualia: http://cognet.mit.edu/posters/TUCSON3/Hardin.html
Various other kinds of qualia inversion are discussed here: http://www.d.umn.edu/~dcole/inverted_spectrum.htm

7:35 - Pseudonormal vision: http://cognet.mit.edu/posters/TUCSON3/Rumelin.html

33:10 - Gould & Lewontin's "Spandrels of San Marco": http://faculty.washington.edu/lynnhank/GouldLewontin.pdf

title: Philosophy of Mind 4.1 - Functionalism
description:
In this video, I explain the basic ideas behind functionalism. I look at how functionalists face a circularity problem, and then explain the two main methods they have used to solve it: Turing Machines and Ramsification.

I will deal with objections to functionalism in the next video.

Re 22:53: http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/church-turing/#Bloopers

title: Philosophy of Mind 3 - The Identity Theory
description:
In this video, I examine the mind-brain identity theory.

Both Mary's Room and multiple realizability have a vast literature, of which I had enough time only to scratch the surface. For more on these topics, see:
http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/qualia-knowledge/
http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/multiple-realizability/

Re 24:27, two articles arguing for the inconceivability of zombies:
http://www.imprint.co.uk/cottrell/jcsmainframe.html
http://pp.kpnet.fi/seirioa/cdenn/unzombie.htm

title: Philosophy of Mind 2 - Logical Behaviourism
description:
The second in my series on philosophy of mind.

Logical behaviourism flourished in the first half of the 20th century. In this video, I outline how the work of the logical positivists and of Wittgenstein lent support to logical behaviourism, and then I examine some of the most serious objections to it.

title: Philosophy of Mind 1 - Substance Dualism
description: The first in a series on philosophy of mind, beginning with substance dualism.

title: Perception: direct realism vs representative realism
description: An introduction to the debate between direct realism and representative realism.

title: Conditionals: the material conditional
description:
In this video, I examine the material analysis of indicative conditionals: the view that "if A then B" is true just in case A is false or B is true.

First, I give a prima facie problem for this analysis: the paradoxes of material implication. I then examine two attempts to defend the material analysis from this problem: Paul Grice's defence, which draws on his theory of conversational implicature; and Frank Jackson's, which draws on the theory conventional implicature and the concept of robustness. Finally I note some further problems that neither of these defences address.

For further reading, I strongly recommend Jonathan Bennett's "A Philosophical Guide to Conditionals", chapters 2 and 3. Stephen Read's "Thinking About Logic", chapter 3, is also a useful, though far less detailed, source.

title: What is meaning? - Verificationism
description: Verificationism is one of the most influential theories of meaning. In this video, I explain what verificationism is and examine some of its consequences.

title: Environmental ethics and Sylvan's "Last Man" argument
description: I briefly outline the three major schools in environmental ethics, then I examine Richard Sylvan's (then known as Richard Routley) "Last Man" thought experiment and some modifications that can be made to it.

title: Doctor Who missing episodes - 9 episodes found!
description: My reaction to the historic discovery of nine missing Doctor Who episodes. There's no interesting information here. Just a rambling expression of joy at this incredible find.

title: Lewis' Triviality Proof
description: An explanation of Lewis' triviality proof.

title: Philosophy of Mathematics: Platonism
description:
A non-technical introduction to platonism in the philosophy of mathematics.

Philosophy of mathematics is important, especially for philosophers interested in metaphysics. Suppose, for instance, you have nominalist tendencies, and you argue against the existence of abstract objects. Well, probably the most important kind of abstract objects are found in mathematics. Any serious nominalist needs to give an account of them.

Yet philosophy of mathematics is also, for obvious reasons, quite technical, and it can be pretty daunting for those who have less mathematical training. Nevertheless, I think the basic arguments can be made accessible to anyone who's interested, and that's what I've tried to do in this video.

For further reading on phil of mathematics, I recommend: "Thinking About Mathematics" by Stewart Shapiro and "Introducing Philosophy of Mathematics" by Michele Friend. These are both fairly orthodox introductions. For an introduction that focuses more on contemporary issues (it has just a few pages devoted to formalism, logicism, and intuitionism, yet a whole chapter on paraconsistent mathematics), I recommend "An Introduction to the Philosophy of Mathematics" by Mark Colyvan.

There is some debate about how exactly to formulate the Quine-Putnam Indispensability Argument. In this video, I've followed Colyvan (see his aforementioned "Introduction").

Re 43:26: I'm not sure why I said that. Obviously, Von Neumann did not hold the absurd belief that every ordinal *is* the ordinal before it; rather he believed that every ordinal is *the set of* all ordinals before it.

Re 1:01:18: I should have noted at this point that in her book "Realism in Mathematics", Maddy spends quite a bit of time answering objection (1).

Plenitudinous platonism is also known by the name "full-blooded platonism". Mark Balaguer's exposition of it can be found in "Platonism and Anti-Platonism in Mathematics". This book is also the source of the third objection to Maddy's views, about the difficulties of avoiding the aggregate theory of sets. The objection is explained in somewhat more detail there.

I said that I consider PP the most interesting form of platonism. This is not quite true. In my opinion, PP is not plenitudinous enough. The problem is that it allows only *consistent* theories. Those of us who are friends of paraconsistency will consider this an unwelcome restriction. Beall presents a more liberal form of PP in this short paper: http://homepages.uconn.edu/~jcb02005/papers/fbplatonism.pdf

title: Russell's Theory of Descriptions 3
description: This series is a basic introduction to Russell's theory of descriptions. In this video, we look at Russell's analysis of definite descriptions and how this analysis is extended to proper names.

title: Russell's Theory of Descriptions 2 - Frege & Meinong
description:
This series is a basic introduction to Russell's theory of descriptions. In this video, we examine two important theories that preceded and inspired Russell's: those of Gottlob Frege and Alexius Meinong.

Some notes to the video:

I've briefly noted some of Russell's criticisms of Frege's and Meinong's theories. There are, of course, plenty of other criticisms; you can find more detailed criticisms of Frege in any good introduction to philosophy of language. Meinong doesn't get so much coverage, perhaps largely because his theory has, for most of the last century, been almost universally rejected and regarded as untenable. This attitude is unfair in my opinion, and is arguably based on misunderstanding. Thus Lycan in his "Philosophy of Language" writes:

"Alexius Meinong insist[s] ... that any possible object of thought - even a self-contradictory one - has being of a sort even though only a few such things are so lucky as to exist in reality as well."

Kenneth Taylor, in "Truth and Meaning": "... there do not exist any non-existent objects, but there do, [Meinong] insists, subsist such objects. ... It is of subsistent objects that we speak when we say truly that the golden mountain does not exist."

Alex Miller, in "Philosophy of Language": "The King of France, even though he doesn't exist, nevertheless subsists."

These quotes describe Russell's earlier theory, not Meinong's theory! It is unfortunate that what are otherwise very fine introductions to philosophy of language are marred by blatant misrepresentations of the views of an important figure. On the other hand, I suppose they can be commended for bothering to attempt to explain Meinong's views (even if only in the space of a few lines), which can't be said of all such introductions (e.g. Devitt & Sterelny's).

I don't know of any introductory book to philosophy of language that explores Meinong's theory. See instead: http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/meinong/#ObjTheOntBeyBeiNonBei or more generally: http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/nonexistent-objects/ .

title: Necessary; analytic; a priori
description:
This video introduces three distinctions of great importance in philosophy: necessary/contingent; analytic/synthetic; a priori/a posteriori. My goal here was simply to introduce the distinctions, so I've kept this very brief and nontechnical, and I don't examine in any great detail the arguments I present. You could devote hours to exploring just one of these distinctions, and you'd still have to skip important information.

13:10 - It may be thought that you could give a modern answer along similar lines by using evolution. So: humans are evolved creatures, and our minds have been shaped by evolution to know certain basic truths about the world. The problem here is that evolution is geared to survival and practicality, not truth. Evolution would dispose us to beliefs that help us survive and that help us navigate the world; there is no reason to suppose that these beliefs are true. Indeed, there is much evidence that many of our commonsense beliefs that may be useful to our everyday concerns are simply false; see the literature on folk physics.

16:20 - Note that this belief might be wrong. There are some experiments that suggest that, under certain special conditions, people can perceive a surface as being wholly coloured with two colours at the same time. Google 'impossible colours'. One such experiment is very simple: simply take, e.g., a blue square and a yellow square, then cross your eyes so the two squares overlap each other. I've tried this myself, and unfortunately I didn't see an 'impossible colour'. Rather, the surface seemed simply to flip back and forth between blue and yellow.

Anyway, if it's true that people can perceive impossible colours, then 'if x is blue all over, then x is not red all over' would indeed be synthetic... but also a posteriori, and false.

22:14 - The point here can be seen if we consider the distinction between de dicto and de re statements, which I explain in this video at 9:30 : http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XLWjJVvQjZ8

Interpreted de re, 'the inventor of the zip invented the zip' is contingent - but a posteriori. De dicto, it's necessary, and a priori. Since the name 'Julius' abbreviates 'the inventor of the zip', 'Julius invented the zip' should be interpreted exactly as is 'the inventor of the zip invented the zip'. So we may apply precisely the same analysis here: read de re, it's contingent a posteriori; read de dicto, it's necessary a priori. But of course, all this ignores that troublesome thicket of rigid designation...

title: Russell's Theory of Descriptions 1 - Some Puzzles
description:
This series is a basic introduction to Russell's theory of descriptions. In this video, we begin by considering some puzzles about singular terms.

Re the distinctions listed at 5:44 : If you're at all unclear about any of these, I introduce all three of them here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0L4GBnzDnRM .

As for my claims regarding on which side of the distinctions (3) and (4) fall, of course there are questionable and have been questioned. It has been held, for example, that identity statements such as "Robert Zimmerman = Bob Dylan" are necessary, not contingent. The very distinction between analytic and synthetic statements has been challenged. Some empiricist philosophers (Mill is the most famous example) have held that even logical truths such as A=A (Robert Zimmerman = Robert Zimmerman) are contingent, a posteriori, synthetic. Etc.

What's clear, though, is that there is some prima facie difference in meaning between (3) and (4), and it's difficult for the commonsense view of singular terms to account for this difference.

title: Ulam games
description: See chapter 4 of Chris Mortensen's "Inconsistent Geometry" for more. As the title of the book suggests, Mortensen discusses Ulam games in the wider context of paraconsistent logic. I don't touch on that in this video.

title: Quine's objections to modal logic 4 - referential opacity
description: In this video, I discuss how modal logic creates referentially opaque contexts.  I also outline the de dicto / de re distinction.

title: Dialetheism 3a - methodological problems - believing contradictions
description:
The Law of Non-Contradiction has been a fundamental, uncontested principle of thought for thousands of years, and this means there are some difficulties trying to set up a debate about it.  In this video, I consider the idea that contradictions simply can't be believed, or, at least, can't be rationally believed.  If either of these ideas is right, dialetheism would be in serious trouble.

For more on the issues discussed in this video, see Priest's "Doubt Truth to be a Liar", chapter 1, section 13 (on negation as cancellation) and chapter 7 (on rationality).

title: Curry's Paradox
description: A brief exposition of Curry's Paradox, first published by Haskell Curry.  It seems to show that, given a special kind of conditional sentence and some very basic logical rules, anything is derivable.

title: Infinity - a brief introduction
description:
This is a brief introduction to the modern mathematical views on infinity.  I've tried to make it accessible to everybody; you don't need any mathematical knowledge to follow it.  I discuss the Hilbert Hotel thought experiment, some very basic set theory, one-to-one correspondence, and Cantor's Diagonal Argument.

I mention a couple times in the video, e.g. at 9:02, that we can take things away from infinity, and still have infinity.  This is true, unless to take infinity from infinity.  Infinity minus infinity is undefined.  It's easy to see why.  Consider the hotel again.  Suppose it's full, and now consider what happens when: (1) everybody in the even-numbered rooms leave, but everybody in the odd-numbered rooms stay; (2) everybody but those in the first million rooms leave; (3) everybody but the person in the first room leaves.  In each of these cases, an infinite number of people have left, but how many remain?  In the first case, infinity -- infinity = infinity.  In the second, infinity -- infinity = one million.  In the third, infinity -- infinity = one.

Re the points around 27:30: the hypothesis that the cardinality of the reals is aleph-one (that is, that there is no infinity in between the naturals or the reals) is known as the "continuum hypothesis".  It has been shown that, on the axioms of standard set theory, it's impossible for the continuum hypothesis to be either proved or disproved.  It's completely independent of the standard axioms.

title: Quine's objections to modal logic 3 - extensionality and intensionality
description:
For his entire philosophical career, Quine was a confirmed defender of extensionality.  In this video, I explain what this means and why it lead to skepticism about modal logic.

At around 4:20, I suggest picking up an intro to phil of language for more info on the extensions of sentences.  A good intro is Morris's "An Introduction to the Philosophy of Language"; chapter 2 deals with Frege's account.  Morris's book also provides, in chapter 6, an overview of the issues we'll be discussing in this series.

Regarding my comment at 13:18 that violations of extensionality are okay in the case of beliefs: in fact, Quine wasn't happy with these, either.  Some of Quine's work on propositional attitudes (propositional attitudes are a kind of mental state, which we express using a verb followed by a "that": "Frank believes that...", "Frank hopes that...", "Frank desires that..." and so on) is very similar to his work on modality.  See, for example, his paper "Quantifiers and Propositional Attitudes".  An accessible introduction to his views on propositional attitudes can be found in the Morris book, chapter 7.

(More generally, Quine's approach to mental entities is often considered an early precursor to the radical eliminativisms of Dennett, Stich, the Churchlands, et al.)

The point is just that violation of extensionality seems to be more acceptable for beliefs, which we all expect to be messy, than for a completed, naturalistic theory of the world, which we expect to be "pure" and well-defined and so on.

title: Dialetheism 2a - the Liar paradox
description:
It's not worth considering dialetheism unless we can point to a few things that might be considered true contradictions.  The most obvious candidates are the paradoxes.  In this video, I examine the most famous and most tenacious of the paradoxes, the Liar paradox.  I explore different kinds of Liar, and outline the responses given by Kripke, Tarski, and Prior.

Further reading on the Liar:

Haack's "Philosophy of Logic", chapter 8
Kirkham's "Theories of Truth", chapter 9
Read's "Thinking About Logic", chapter 6
Sainsbury's "Paradoxes", chapter 6 (this book provides, as the title suggests, a good and accessible introduction to a whole bunch of paradoxes)

Priest's work can be found in chapter 1 of "In Contradiction" and part 3 of "Beyond the Limits of Thought".

The point of this video is just to demonstrate how obstinate the Liar is: there's unlikely to be a solution that will preserve all our intuitions.

title: Five Poems for John Cage
description:
Five mesostics, each constructed using one of Cage's books as a source text.  The books I used: 'Silence', 'A Year from Monday', 'M', 'Empty Words', 'X'.

The background music is a piece by me.

title: The problem of deduction
description:
Anybody with an interest in philosophy is aware of the problem of induction.  But there are philosophers who have suggested that deduction is equally vulnerable to a skeptical attack.

Susan Haack's paper, "The Justification of Deduction", is available online here: http://www.as.miami.edu/phi/haack/Justification%20of%20Deduction%20reprint%202010.pdf

Carroll's "What the Tortoise Said to Achilles": http://courseweb.stthomas.edu/KWKemp/Logic/R/Tortoise.pdf

Thomson's "What Achilles Should Have Said to the Tortoise": http://www.math.dartmouth.edu/~matc/Readers/HowManyAngels/Achilles.html

Regarding the points discussed around 26:00 - 27:11, cf. for example: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logical_harmony & Belnap's paper "Tonk, Plonk, & Plink": http://www.pitt.edu/~belnap/24tonkplonkandplink.pdf

title: Modal logic 2.6 - summary so far
description: I briefly examine the relationships between the systems we've seen so far.

title: Modal logic 2.5 - invalid arguments in normal modal logics
description: I do some trees for invalid arguments in B and S4 and then construct counterexamples.  The methods used for B and S4 (and for M and S5) are pretty much the same as for K, so if you've worked through the previous videos, this should be fairly simple stuff.

title: Quine's objections to modal logic 2 - use and mention
description:
Quine once said that modal logic was "conceived in sin".  In this video, I explain exactly what that sin was.

Note: this is more a criticism of Lewis's motivation for developing modal logic, than of modal logic in general.  You can skip this video if you want to go straight to the really substantial objections.  (However, later videos will probably be easier to follow if you've seen this one first.)

title: Modal logic 2.4 - a trick for trees in S5
description: A simple method for simplifying S5 trees.

title: For a lovely rodent - Minesweeper
description: How to play Minesweeper.

title: Modal logic 2.3 - two important truth tree rules, and a space saving method
description: I discuss two important rules you need to be aware of, and demonstrate a simple trick I sometimes use to save space when doing trees.

title: Quine's objections to modal logic 1 - historical background
description: I briefly discuss the development of modern modal logic, to set the scene for Quine's attack.

title: Dialetheism supplement - a simple paraconsistent logic
description:
(An error: at 5:25, it should read ''R(p arrow q, 1) iff either R(p, 0) or R(q, 1)''.)

A supplement to my series on dialetheism, for those familiar with formal propositional logic.   If you don't have a background in logic, you can skip this video.

Priest has outlined his Logic of Paradox in a number of sources; the most easily available is probably his book "In Contradiction", chapter 5.

title: Modal logic 2.2 - more on the accessibility relation
description: I examine the basic structure of trees in B, S4 and S5.

title: Dialetheism 1 - preliminary remarks
description:
Setting the scene for a series on dialetheism, the view that there are true contradictions.

A good introductory article to paraconsistent logics: http://plato.stanford.edu/entries/logic-paraconsistent/

title: Modal logic 2.1 - the systems M, B, S4 & S5
description:
I discuss how we can impose conditions on the accessibility relation to generate new systems.  I briefly analyse three such conditions and then introduce four new systems.

Errors: at about 9:25, that should be not possibly p, 1.

at about 13:52, S4 should be "M + transitivity".

title: Poem for David Lewis
description: A 50% mesostic for philosopher David K. Lewis...

title: Poem for Paul Churchland
description: A 50% mesostic for philosopher Paul Churchland...

title: Poem for Richard Sylvan (Routley)
description:
A short 50% mesostic for the philosopher Richard Sylvan...

McMaster University, because they're lovely, lovely people, have made "Exploring Meinong's Jungle and Beyond" available for free on their digital commons site:

http://digitalcommons.mcmaster.ca/meinong/1/

In my opinion, it remains a crime against philosophy that such a classic text (along with a bunch of Sylvan's other work) is still unavailable in the usual formats.

title: Modal logic 1.6 - an alternative truth tree method
description: I discuss a slightly different truth tree method for K.

title: Modal logic 1.5a - soundness & completeness
description: I briefly outline the concepts of soundness and completeness.

title: Modal logic 1.5 - logical consequence in K
description: I discuss the notion of logical consequence, and outline two important approaches to consequence: the semantic/model-theoretic approach, and the syntactic/proof-theoretic approach.  I focus on the system K, but it should be easy to see how the ideas can generalize to other systems.

title: Modal logic 1.4 - truth trees for invalid arguments in K
description: I use truth trees to show the invalidity of two arguments in K, and I explain how truth trees provide an easy method for finding counterexamples to invalid arguments.

title: Modal logic 1.3 - a strange property of K
description: I discuss a rather counterintuitive property of K.  I was going to mention this in the previous video but forgot to put it in there...

title: Modal logic 1.2 - truth trees for system K
description: The rules for truth trees in system K, and some advice about constructing trees in K.  I then use trees to prove the validity of two simple arguments.

title: Modal logic 1.1 - system K - introduction
description: An introduction to the basic concepts of the system K in modal logic.

title: Modal logic 0.2 - basic introduction
description: A brief, intuitive introduction to the basic concepts of modal logic.  The box & diamond operators, necessity & possibility, possible worlds, etc.  If you're already familiar with all this stuff, you can skip this video.

title: Modal logic 0.1 - basic introduction
description:
A brief, intuitive introduction to the basic concepts of modal logic.  The box & diamond operators, necessity & possibility, possible worlds, etc.  If you're already familiar with all this stuff, you can skip this video.

Part 2: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0djILNja3ZE

title: Truth trees for propositional logic 2
description: A quick explanation of how to use truth trees for propositional logic.

title: Truth trees for propositional logic 1
description:
A quick explanation of how to use truth trees with propositional logic.

Part 2 is here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wi7sTcF-z60
